The IRS imposes penalties on taxpayers for various reasons, including failing to file a tax return on time, failing to pay taxes owed, or providing inaccurate information. However, the IRS also offers penalty abatement—a process that allows taxpayers to request a reduction or removal of certain penalties under specific circumstances. Understanding how penalty abatement works can save taxpayers significant amounts of money and stress. 

What is Penalty Abatement? 

Penalty abatement is the IRS’s way of offering relief to taxpayers who can demonstrate a valid reason for not complying with tax laws. This relief is not automatic; taxpayers must meet certain criteria and follow the appropriate procedures to request it. Penalty abatement typically applies to failure-to-file, failure-to-pay, and accuracy-related penalties but does not usually extend to interest charges. However, there are some cases in which interest charges are also removed.  

Types of Penalty Abatement 

There are several types of IRS penalty abatement. You may not qualify for all of them, so it’s important to know what each type is and their eligibility requirements.  

First-Time Penalty Abatement 

First-Time Penalty Abatement (FTA) is the most common form of relief. It is designed for taxpayers who have maintained a history of compliance. To qualify, you must have filed all required returns or extensions and paid, or arranged to pay, any taxes due. For instance, if you accidentally missed a filing deadline but have no prior penalties in the last three tax years, you may be eligible for FTA. This type of relief serves as an incentive for taxpayers to maintain compliance with tax regulations. 

Reasonable Cause Relief 

Reasonable Cause Relief is another form of penalty abatement provided when taxpayers can prove that their failure to comply was due to circumstances beyond their control. Examples include a serious illness, the death of a close family member, or a natural disaster. To qualify, taxpayers must present evidence to support their claims, such as medical records, insurance reports, or documented timelines that explain how the event prevented compliance.  

Statutory Exception Relief 

Statutory Exception Relief applies in cases where a penalty arises due to incorrect IRS guidance or other statutory circumstances. For example, if the IRS provided written advice that a taxpayer followed in good faith but later determined to be erroneous, the taxpayer might qualify for relief under this category. This ensures fairness when taxpayers are misled by authoritative guidance and penalized as a result. Documentation of the IRS’s guidance and evidence of compliance with that guidance are critical for obtaining this type of abatement. 

Who is Eligible for Penalty Abatement? 

Eligibility for penalty abatement depends on the type of relief being requested. Generally, taxpayers must demonstrate a history of compliance for First-Time Penalty Abatement. For reasonable cause relief, taxpayers need evidence such as documented proof of medical conditions or natural disasters. Statutory exceptions require documentation that aligns with the specific statutory circumstances or incorrect IRS guidance. 

How to Request Penalty Abatement 

To request penalty abatement, begin by checking your eligibility to ensure you meet the criteria for First-Time Penalty Abatement, reasonable cause, or statutory exception relief. Next, contact the IRS directly at the number listed on the penalty notice you received or use the general IRS customer service line. Taxpayers may also file Form 843, “Claim for Refund and Request for Abatement,” to formally request relief. This approach is particularly useful for claims based on reasonable cause or statutory exceptions. When submitting your request, include relevant documents such as medical records, insurance claims, or correspondence with the IRS to substantiate your case. The IRS may take several weeks to process your request, so it is important to monitor the progress and keep copies of all communications for your records. 

Additional Considerations 

While penalties may be abated, the interest accrued on those penalties often remains unless the underlying penalty itself is eliminated entirely. If your abatement request is denied, you can appeal through the IRS’s Office of Appeals. Having strong supporting evidence is critical in such cases. Tax professionals can provide valuable guidance and representation when requesting penalty abatement, especially for complex cases involving reasonable cause. 

Why Penalty Abatement Matters 

Penalties can add a significant financial burden to already strained taxpayers. Understanding and using penalty abatement options can ease these burdens and help taxpayers stay compliant moving forward. Whether you qualify for First-Time Abatement, reasonable cause relief, or another type, knowing the steps to request abatement is key to resolving tax issues effectively. 

Tax Help for Those Seeking IRS Penalty Abatement 

Taxpayers who face penalties should act promptly to explore their abatement options, as the IRS generally prefers to work with those who proactively address their tax situations. By leveraging the tools available, you can mitigate penalties and achieve financial peace of mind. If dealing with the IRS on your own seems too intimidating, consider consulting with an experienced tax professional for help.
